values.description:
Previously “exp\_ramp” and “exp\_ramp\_t” defaulted to a truncation of 1.0 and a truncation type of "linear". This meant that if these parameters were not set, the function would try to truncate the ramp to an output value of 1.0 units \(and fail completely if this was not within the range of the ramp\).

I saw two options for fixing this to give more intuitive behaviour. First, the default truncation type could be changed to "exponential" -- truncating as a fraction of the time of the ramp. This probably should be done eventually, as this is the behaviour of every other type of ramp, however this could lead to backwards compatibility issues for labs that use truncation but don't explicitly set the type. Instead, I chose the second option, which was to set the default value to “None” and check for this, ensuring that no truncation occurs when none is set.
values.title: Changed default behaviour of exponential ramps when "truncation" keyword argument is not set.

summary.raw:
Previously “exp\_ramp” and “exp\_ramp\_t” defaulted to a truncation of 1.0 and a truncation type of "linear". This meant that if these parameters were not set, the function would try to truncate the ramp to an output value of 1.0 units \(and fail completely if this was not within the range of the ramp\).

I saw two options for fixing this to give more intuitive behaviour. First, the default truncation type could be changed to "exponential" -- truncating as a fraction of the time of the ramp. This probably should be done eventually, as this is the behaviour of every other type of ramp, however this could lead to backwards compatibility issues for labs that use truncation but don't explicitly set the type. Instead, I chose the second option, which was to set the default value to “None” and check for this, ensuring that no truncation occurs when none is set.
summary.html:
Previously “exp_ramp” and “exp_ramp_t” defaulted to a truncation of 1.0 and a truncation type of "linear". This meant that if these parameters were not set, the function would try to truncate the ramp to an output value of 1.0 units (and fail completely if this was not within the range of the ramp).

I saw two options for fixing this to give more intuitive behaviour. First, the default truncation type could be changed to "exponential" -- truncating as a fraction of the time of the ramp. This probably should be done eventually, as this is the behaviour of every other type of ramp, however this could lead to backwards compatibility issues for labs that use truncation but don't explicitly set the type. Instead, I chose the second option, which was to set the default value to “None” and check for this, ensuring that no truncation occurs when none is set.
